page.title: 06Mineral Recovery at Nanjizel
page.content: Evidence of alluvial deposits having been exploited is shown by small piles of stones and gravel on each side of a stream running into the cove. Written facts, based on a paper to the{Royal {Cornwall Geological Society}in 1845 by Mr. Joseph Carne, refer to a{stamping {mill on the edge of the cliff.}Traces of the race from "four ponds in the vicinity of Lower Bosistow Farm" can still be seen. A local name for the northern of the two valleys into the bay is{Stamps Bottoms}and early maps show a Stamps Farm on the Sennen side of the boundary. A description of the terrain shows it to be much as it is today.{Old millstones,}on the beach until recently,{support the other name for Nanjizel,{Mill Bay.}Evidence suggests{corn grinding was the main {use of the stream,}with ore processing ocurring spasmodically.
